name: A/B Testing
description: Compare two versions of a webpage or app against specific metrics to test which performs better. Also known as split testing, this technique can help you test which variations of copy, visual style, or layout perform better.

links.title: A Beginner’s Guide To A/B Testing: An Introduction
The Ultimate Guide To A/B Testing
What is A/B Testing?

name: Affinity Diagramming
description: Also known as the KJ method, you can use affinity diagramming to facilitate group concensus, organize disparate concepts, and establish priorities from subjective, qualitative data.

links.title: The KJ-Technique: A Group Process for Establishing Priorities
Affinity Diagrams: Tips and Tricks
Affinity Diagramming

name: Analytics
description: By tracking and analyzing usage data for apps and sites, you can make better informed decisions, predict potential future results, and discover areas for improvement. Analytics can tell you what’s happened recently or what’s happening now, but not necessarily why.

links.title: Complete Beginner’s Guide to Analytics
An Analytics-First Approach to UX, Part 1
Designing with Analytics

name: Animated Prototype
description: Animated prototypes help you convey motion, transitions, and interactions more explicitly, giving a more final vision of the feel for your website or app.

links.title: How to Get Animations Out of Your Head
Prototyping Animation with Keynote
A New Mobile UX Design Material

name: Card Sorting
description: Card sorting exercises uncover how your users think about the way content and navigation are organized. In open card sorting, you give more power to participants to create the structure and rename both content and categories using what feels natural to them. Closed card sorting is helpful to understanding where new content fits in an existing structure.

links.title: Improving Your Information Architecture With Card Sorting: A Beginner’s Guide
Card Sorting: A Definitive Guide
Card Sorting - Usability.gov

name: Code Prototype
description: Coding your prototypes can be helpful for testing not just whether a design concept resonates with users, but whether it’s technically feasible and how it works on different devices.

links.title: Prototyping in Code
Building Prototypes in HTML and CSS
Introduction to Mobile Prototyping with HTML, CSS and JavaScript

name: Content Inventory & Audit
description: By cataloging the contents of a website or app, your content inventory tells you what content exists, where it can be found, who maintains it, and more. From your inventory, you can run a content audit to determine what stays, what goes, and what needs to be updated.

links.title: Doing a Content Inventory (Or, a Mind-Numbingly Detailed Odyssey Through Your Web Site
The Content Inventory is Your Friend
How to Conduct A Content Audit

name: Design Critique
description: Well-run design critiques can uncover problems, smooth rough edges, and identify future opportunities even before running a concept by users. By focusing on whether the design solves a given problem rather than subjective elements, critiques drive a design toward the best possible solution.

links.title: How to Run a Design Critique
The Art of the Design Critique
Taming the Elephant: Design Critiques with Non-Designers

name: Design Studio
description: Design studios happen when you bring together a motley crew from across your team or company, give them an interesting problem to solve, and a very short span of time to come up with as many visual ideas as possible. By quickly sketching out many ideas, critiquing them briefly, then diverging for more ideation, you can come up with many different solutions to a problem to kickstart the creative process.

links.title: Design Studio Workshop: Adding Up the Benefits
How to Run a Design Studio in 90 Minutes or Less
3 Steps to Running Design Studio Workshops

name: Diary Study
description: Your users don’t exist in a specific moment in time and neither do the problems that necessitate your products. Diary studies help you understand behavior and patterns over longer periods of time, give deeper insight into the customer journey, and help better illuminate user habits.

links.title: Diary Studies: Understanding Long-Term User Behavior and Experiences
Jumpstart Design Research with a Diary Study
How to Get Feedback Over Time with Diary Studies

name: Discovery Research
description: Observe users in their environment (workplace, home, etc.), interview stakeholders, define the problems you’ll be solving, and better empathize with your users. Discovery research helps you decide what problem you’ll be solving.

links.title: Start Deep in Discovery
Interviewing Users
Complete Beginner’s Guide to UX Research

name: Element Collage
description: The element collage is more specific than style tiles or mood boards, but less tied together than mockups or prototypes. With an element collage, you can design individual components and styles irrespective of their place in the final screen.

links.title: Element Collages
Element Collages... are FUN!
Visual Design Explorations

name: Field Testing
description: When you see people working, playing, or acting where they feel right at home, you can learn a lot more about them than you can in a lab. Field testing lets you observe users where they use the products you make. Simply by paying attention, you can see what else vies for their attention, what their priorities are, and what their habits are.

links.title: Field Studies: The Best Tool to Discover User Needs
Field Studies Done Right: Fast and Observational
Usability Testing Demystified

name: Focus Group
description: Running concepts past a focus group can be a quick way to get quick reactions from a diverse group of people. Focus groups are great for testing reactions, perceptions, and the potential value, and not very good for observational discovery or testing usability.

links.title: What is a UX Focus Group?
Do’s and Don’ts for Focus Groups
The Use and Misuse of Focus Groups

name: Guerilla Testing
description: Get out of the building and talk with potential users on the streets and in the coffee shops. With some planning and a little time with a bunch of diverse users, you can get a good idea of what works and what doesn’t.

links.title: The Art of Guerilla Usability Testing
7 Step Guide to Guerrilla Usability Testing: DIY Usability Testing Method
Guerrilla Research Tactics and Tools

name: Heatmap
description: Heatmaps help you quickly understand what attracts your users’ attention on your website or app by turning data into a visual overlay that can illuminate what parts get the most clicks or other interaction.

links.title: Understanding Simple Heat Maps for Smarter UI Design
Using Heatmaps to Improve Usability and Conversions
Mouse Heatmaps

name: Heuristic Evaluation
description: Have an expert (or better, a set of experts) review your app or website against a set of broad principles to identify potential problems and gauge their severity.

links.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
How to Run an Heuristic Evaluation
An Overview of Expert Heuristic Evaluations

name: High-Fidelity Prototype
description: A high fidelity prototype gives a close facsimile of the production version. It can feel real to users you test with, many clients or stakeholders are more comfortable with it, and it can serve as a starting point for developers to build from.

links.title: Hi-Fi Prototyping: Design is Our Muse, Code is Our Medium
High Fidelity Rapid Prototyping
The Benefits of High Fidelity Prototyping

name: Journey Map
description: Journey Maps document a user’s experience across multiple touchpoints, from their discovery of the product or service (or even before) to their full engagement with it, including emotional impact. They tell the story of how a user engages with your product over time.

links.title: How to Create a Customer Journey Map
How to Run a Customer Journey Mapping Workshop
The Value of Customer Journey Maps: A UX Designer’s Personal Journey

name: Lab Testing
description: Testing in a dedicated UX lab can give you more scientifically accurate results and reproducible experiments, but may not be as quick and efficient as other testing methods.

links.title: Lab Usability Testing: What, Why, How Much?
Streamlining Usability Testing by Avoiding the Lab
Traveling Usability Lab

name: Low-Fidelity Prototype
description: Get your ideas out of your head and in front of potential users more quickly with low-fidelity prototypes. The lower the fidelity, the more quickly you can test and iterate over new versions.

links.title: The Skeptic’s Guide To Low-Fidelity Prototyping
Why Low-Fidelity Prototyping Kicks Butt for Customer-Driven Design
A Guide to Prototype Fidelity
The KJ-Technique: A Group Process for Establishing Priorities
The KJ-Technique: A Group Process for Establishing Priorities
